It just randomly occurred to me that you could avoid compatibility problems and still encourage Flash to die by using <video> as fallback for Flash, instead of the other way around.
So your site still works even if Flash isn't installed, even if not quite how you'd like it.
interesting thought ---- the part about encouraging flash to die that is :)
I should say, your site might still work if Flash isn't installed.

http://coolreader.org/crengine.htm
CREngine is an open source E-Book viewer library development project.
2 different DOM tree implementations
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FBReader
Supported formats include EPUB, FictionBook, HTML, plucker, PalmDoc, zTxt, TCR, RTF, OEB, Non-DRM'ed mobipocket and plain-text.
http://raphaeljs.com/gear.html

AryehGregor: yeah, basically the criteria for keeping it was "is it mature, has it been successful in the market, and is it something that could not be reused in other specs", based on http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2010Jan/att-0218/issue-76-decision.html
Part of me would love to see what happened if someone decided to apply those criteria to the entire spec
Hixie: what's up with the w3c cvs server?
not sure, MikeSmithXX said he'd look into it
it picked a bad time to pitch a fit
but then, I guess it's always a bad time
anyway, I posted a CfC to publish the new document
it's been refusing changes for a few days
might as well put one out for http://dev.w3.org/cvsweb/~checkout~/html5/2dcontext/Overview.html?content-type=text/html as well
if you ask on the list I'll do it
k, will do shortly
got some maintenance to do first
k
othermaciej: what's up is that there seems to be a stale lock file for the last 36 hours or so now
MikeSmithXX: ugh
MikeSmithXX: do you have shell access to that machine? should be easy to remove manually if so
i guess with the splt out microdata section having he vocabularies in it, we don't need the separate vocab specs any more
should i cvs remove them?
it'd make my life easier
othermaciej: yeah, I have shell access to the cvs repository, but when I go into the cvs filesystem there, I see all the ,v files but not lock files anywhere
Hixie: yeah, sure
the messages say that its waiting on a lock for user "www-data", which leads me to believe that the problem is there's a hung cvs process on the dev.w3.org mirror
but I don't have shell access to that machine
as soon as someone for Europe systems team gets on, I think it should get fixed pretty quickly
but I do want to find out for the future what the hell the cause of the problem was
MikeSmith: do you see any cvs processes running on dev.w3.org?
MikeSmith: if you have root you could just kill those maybe
I can't even remember how cvs does lockfiles
othermaciej: I have no shell access to dev.w3.org so can't check ps or top or anything there
csv docs say that it uses lock files with "#" prefixes but I find none of those in the repository
I do find some LOCKS directories but none that correspond to the html5 spec dir
weird
maybe for the future I can ask for root access to dev.w3.org
actually, not maybe -- I will ask
I will say that often when I report problems with dev.w3.org, the response I've gotten from systems team is the response to the "Doctor, it hurts when I do this." complaint
I have been told that dev.w3.or was never intended to be a platform for publishing documents, but instead only for making software available
and that it is underpowered as a publishing server and so we should not be surprised when it has problems
to which my response is that we and many others have in fact been using it as a publishing platform for a long while, so maybe it's time we made it work the way it should
does the w3c have any other way to maintain and track editor's drafts?
in any case, it seems like a stuck lock is something that should just be fixed
MikeSmith: what happens when you ask "so what are we supposed to use for public version control of editor's drafts?"?
Hixie: what is the about:blank synchronicity in HTML5 based on?
Hixie: that is, which engine did you reverse engineer?
everyone does it and pages depend on it, iirc
Hixie: Gecko does something in that direction but not exactly
Hixie: see http://groups.google.com/group/mozilla.dev.platform/msg/9853d685c3fc9652
i saw that earlier
i'm happy to make the spec say whatever the browser vendors are willing to implement
(as far as this goes)
Hixie: I guess I'll have to ask Boris to state what that is
I don't understand the docshell well enough
it would be ideal if you could get the webkit guys on board as well
when i talk to them they seem to take this about:blank-is-synchronous thing pretty seriously
Hixie: is about:blank loading in WebKit really truly synchronous always?
as in: does the about:blank DOM always get created without a trip through the event loop when a browsing context is created or navigated to about:blank?
how do the events fire?
dunno, test it
I guess I have to write a pure-HTML test for this
Mozilla has tests that use a XUL harness
and the tests run in the same XUL harness so that when the events break, it's hard to see what broke

you should be able to commit now
thanks
sorry for the ridiculously long delay
no worries

no hostile questions

annevk: How do I phrase it less hostile?
note that the widget specification makes it possible to ship, say, windows executables, and still conform to the spec
phrasing it less doesn't make it less :p
I'm still wondering, though. Magic numbers and file extensions seem quite popular.
hsivonen: except, it doesn't seem time-frozen
at least not based on the spec linked from that page
Dashiva, I can't really think of anything
virtuelv: thanks
virtuelv: widget specs allowing Windows executables doesn't seem quite nice
Dashiva: email apps deciding between text/plain, text/enriched, text/html (and maybe text/rtf?) email bodies for rendering
Yeah, that's a good one. Email probably has more reliable labeling too.
hsivonen: P&C is a packaging format specification
Dashiva: for message bodies maybe. I'd expect attachment labeling to be semirandom
Dashiva: but I don't know
hsivonen: i've skimmed to the end of that MPEG-U spec now, it also seems to be a user-agent specification and interaction via DLNA
Attachments probably get by on having a filename
wonders who actually runs a DLNA network at home
attaching a small computer to a TV seems like a more versatile and reliable solution
SVN uses MIME types to determine text vs binary - does that count?
hsivonen: All of this is coming, like it or not
http://www.opera.com/business/solutions/devices/tv/
Philip`: Not much, if it's just a "starts with text/ or doesn't" check
Although I suppose if the mime-type is stored, then applications accessing the svn repo might use the mime-type for useful things
Many web crawlers look at MIME types to work out whether they've got an HTML file they should parse and explore, or another file they should index in other ways
wonders how seriously consumer electronics are going to handle security updates
Dashiva: Browsers accessing the SVN web interface use the mime-type for useful things :-)
Not sure about other client programs, though
hsivonen: Depends on how seriously they take consumers bricking their devices on botched firmware upgrades?
hsivonen: I dunno, but my TV has upgradable firmware
Dashiva: I don't know if TV vendors are more concerned with bricking or delivering timely updates for cross-Origin security holes
(I suppose hijacking local files is a bit less of an issue on TVs)
wonders if there's statistics on how many people upgrade firmware
(I'd assume it's about 0%, in cases where it's not entirely automatic)
especially when one's foremost expectation is that firmware updates *remove* functionality by blacklisting leaked DRM keys
I assume Sony keeps statistics on firmware updates, because the manual said they reserve the right to track the MAC ids of network-connected TVs
(or something along those lines; I've never connected a Sony TV to a network)
I assume that TVs will have mandatory auto updates when connected to a network
wonders where Sony, Samsung, etc. expect end users to obtain their MPEG-4 in non-standard container video files for DLNA viewing
From their proprietary online stores?
do they have online stores where one can buy Matroska files without DRM?
wonders if bugmail arrives late or if Hixie kept fixing bugs past his announced bed time
hsivonen, firmware updates that remove leaked DRM keys are, IIRC, somewhat forced upon users when they insert discs produced and bought after the blacklisting.
so if a disc says the device's key isn't valid, it won't be able to play the disc without a firmware upgrade
Lachy: ah. I don't really know how this works.
ok, here's a brief summary:
Lachy: I was thinking of HDCP over HDMI stopping to support a picture source
it would suck pretty badly if one's video card stopped interoperating with a TV because the TV downloaded a blacklist with the GPU on it
due to the GPU having gotten cracked elsewhere
or something like that
Hardware vendors for blu-ray players are issued device keys that are stored somewhere in the firmware, usually in a way that's difficult for end users to access.
I don't even know what the threat scenarios are here
The blu-ray discs have information on them pertaining to the set of keys that are valid. (This isn't just a simple list, it uses some complicated mathematics that I won't even try to explain)
The AACS have a way to blacklist device keys by altering that information on future discs
Lachy: does this affect the HDCP hop in any way?
Lachy: does the TV and the Blu-Ray player need to be updated in sync or something like that?
I don't believe so. If the player is able to decode and play the disc, the HDCP is a separate encryption step
but I'm not an expert on this and my summary was an overly simplified summary
anyway, this DRM stuff isn't a good background for motivating users to approve the installation of browser or Flash updates to their TVs
I've never had a TV that could accept firmware updates, and until it was mentioned a few minutes ago, it didn't occur to me that anyone would do it.
I have one that could accept updates, but the TV works now as a display for a Mac Mini, so I haven't taken any chances with updates
I've never tried the built-in networking or the widget engine on the TV

vaguely remembers an explanation that the complicated mathematics is kind of like there's a binary tree with device keys as leafs, and the disc can contain a set of keys corresponding to nodes in the tree, where each node key can be combined with a device key in a subtree of that node, in order to decode the disc
in fact, I've never even connected it to a TV antenna cord

and so the first discs just need a key at the root node, and later you can blacklist any arbitrary device key by only giving node keys at the nodes that aren't its ancestors (i.e. by giving O(depth of tree) keys)
which seems like a clever approach
has never had a TV that required updates but does have a Wii that does (and sometimes has mandatory updates)
(and a Wii and a TV are about the same level of consuer hardware as far as I'm concerned)
*consumer
mandatory updates when DRM is involved can be a real pain. I've been affected by Spotify's mandatory DRM updates, which wouldn't allow me to play my songs on my iphone till I upgraded the spotify app
that's what made me decide to stop paying for spotify
hasn't had any problems with spotify
(from that point of view)
(although I don't have an iPhone or anything fancy)
I haven't really used Spotify on S60 after installing it
I generally don't listen to music while mobile
does XML make it possible to introduce carriage returns in PI data?
I don't see how that would be possible

"To simplify the tasks of applications, the XML processor MUST behave as if it normalized all line breaks in external parsed entities (including the document entity) on input, before parsing, by translating both the two-character sequence #xD #xA and any #xD that is not followed by #xA to a single #xA character."
I can't see any way past that
and NCRs aren't supported in PIs

No argument on that.
Details got removed? Sigh. Do I have to write a change proposal or something to get it back?

Details was cute, but I don't think it was more than marginally useful.

so I think the first step is to reopen http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=8379 and provide rationale
AryehGregor: I find myself wanting it really often and having to go to script just to get a disclosure triangle is overkill
Lachy: as I read that, it is technically only the "commenter" (i.e. the bug filer" who should reopen bugs)
Details would have been enormously useful to me. It's a pattern I use all the time with JavaScript.
AryehGregor: Expando sections are a very common idiom on the web, and great for information accessiblity.
Lachy: (that might be a bug in the document though, I will check with othermaciej)
adactio: how do you avoid poisoning browser-native <details>?
hsivonen: What do you mean?

hsivonen: well, I haven't actually used the <details> element itself but I imagine it wouldn't be too tricky to test for native support in JavaScript (in a similar way to checking for native input types).
It's not difficult.  <details> has an open method you can test for.
As I said, it's the *pattern* that I use all the time. It would be nice to see such a common pattern move from a scripted to a declarative solution (much like all those new input types).
adactio: ok
sighs at the removal of <details>
TabAtkins: I mean it's perilous to use JS emulation for an HTML5 feature before there's a native impl so you can test your JS impl gets out of the way cleanly
hsivonen: Sure, but like I said, there's an easy hook for testing.  document.createElement('details').open should return undefined if it's not natively handled.
maybe Shelley's removal bugs don't represent WG consensus
daedb: It hasn't been removed, just moved
Hopefully a massively incomplete implementation of <details> won't show up in a public build.
Dashiva: Political bullshit like moving it to another version of the spec is worse than useless.
I use <details> right now with the .open testing on a few intranet sites.
Political bullshit doesn't disappear just because we know it's bullshit
Wait. Wait. Wait. Is <details> in HTML5 or not?

I added a request to un-kill details Found this the other day by clicking the tabs at the top of labs.opera.com and wondered if you minded if I give it a spring clean to mention HTML5, widgets, mobile best practices etc.

Would it be useful to have something on this page that talks about our policy with patents, too? Eg, lift some text from http://www.opera.com/company/vision/
We believe in a patent-free Web.
adactio: not

Opera Software does not believe innovation in the software industry is protected or encouraged by software patents. In particular, we believe interoperability on the Internet should be encouraged, and we actively work to ensure that software patents do not stand in the way of interoperability.

As a highly innovative company, Opera Software comes up with many ideas and concepts that are patentable. In some situations, we will apply for software patents as a way to protect ourselves from attacks by other aggressive patent holders.

I am utterly confused by the WHATWG site now. This page: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/ links to "HTML5" latest draft, but when I go there I'm told I'm reading "WHATWG HTML (Including HTML5)."
utterly confused or you think you discovered a bug? :)
That page is greatly out of date
it should prolly redirect to http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/FAQ#What_are_the_various_versions_of_the_spec.3F
and that entry should be moved out of HTML5
I guess the whole FAQ needs an update to take into account new realities
oh well, maybe for when I'm back
Re <details>: I realize it's very common, but there are zillions of common things people use JS for.  Why should we add this one to HTML and not all the others?
will now be challenged to provide examples, which he'll be forced to come up with off the top of his head, so they'll be easily shot down and everyone else will smugly claim victory.
So, just to get this straight in my own head: there is no longer a spec named HTML5 at the WHATWG. There is a spec named HTML5 at the W3C. There is a WHATWG spec named HTML.
adactio: at least a while ago, whatwg.org also had a document that corresponded to W3C HTML5
It still does
I'm doing my damndest to evangelise HTML5 to front end developers and designers but you guys don't make it easy.
I think the idea is that HTML is a constantly evolving language
Sheesh! And I thought the W3C was bureaucratic and Kafkaesque.
"HTML5" is a snapshot of that language (in terms of features)
adactio - http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/html5/
The W3C process is designed around snapshots, so the HTML WG is trying to develop and publish HTML5
thats the one you want - it is textually identical to the w3c spec
I'm just wondering how many more features/sections will be (re)moved before HTML5 is little more than a prettier version of HTML4.
The WHATWG doesn't really have a process, so it's mainly doing HTML (which is the HTML5 snapshot plus extra features)
adactio: I think Hixie said when W3C HTML5 efforts started that WHATWG HTML would remain a superset of W3C HTML5 if the W3C went into the weeds
So there is no multi-page version of HTML5 on the WHATWG site? There is a multipage version of a spec called HTML (which includes HTML5) but only one version of HTML5.
(but there is a WHATWG copy of the HTML5 document, for people who prefer its licensing or colours)
adactio - check http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/html5/
its the one you want
adactio: Yes
cardona507: mult-page, please?
The WHATWG doesn't have a multipage version of that, only of the superset language
Anyone know if Moz intends to implement the RDFa DOM API when that is spec'd?
though it should be easy for someone to run the multipager tool on the HTML5 document if they want
adactio - there isn't a whatwg multipage version - but here is the w3c multipag http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/spec.html
(and publish it somewhere for anyone who wants it)
*multipage
adactio: apparently, the WG decision to remove Microdata triggered the pre-announced weeds protocol

For. Fuck's. Sake. As if this stuff wasn't confusing enough for authors already. Now they have to put up with stupid spec obfuscation for the sake of some minor semantic victory for someone somewhere.
Priority of constituencies, my arse.
The WHATWG couldn't make the spec more author-unfriendly if they tried.
The spec isn't meant to be friendly to typical authors, it's meant to be precise.
You can't have an easy-to-use spec that's precise.
Don't blame the WHATWG, blame Hixie :-)
Ha! "spec," I said. As if there were just one.
They're all subsets of the HTML Complete spec.
So you can just use that one if you want.
adactio: there is just one: Complete
Some people complained the spec was too big.
And are still complaining the spec is too big.
one spec to rule them all - and one spec to bind them....
Someone should make a Venn diagram of all the spec documents
AryehGregor: the design principles would seem to indicate to me that the spec is supposed to be easy to use (as well as precise).
adactio: looks like Hixie can't do what you like and what Shelley likes at the same time :-(
adactio, no, the features it specifies are supposed to be easy to use.  It's not meant for ordinary authors to use it to learn HTML, you can't do that and be a good reference at the same time.
People will still need separate tutorials to actually learn how to use HTML, unless they're crazy spec-reading people like us.

hsivonen: I didn't realise that I was supposed to the bug tracker as my own personal bitching space. There are plenty of things I question in HTML5, but I would never file my personal issues as "bugs": I take them to the list for discussion.
now HTML5 is something for everyone: a series of small hard-to-track specs or one big cross-referenced thing
adactio, Shelley likes to use the bug tracker instead of mailing lists.
Also, she likes to raise every quibble she has as a tracker issue.
Apparently to ensure that things are properly discussed by the whole bureaucratic W3C procedure.
The bug tracker is the only way to guarantee a response within the HTML WG
AryehGregor: Yeah, I've noticed.
Rather than, you know, saying it doesn't matter and so who cares, let's just let the editor do what he feels like.
And the issue tracker is the only way to force a non-technical solution...
Or a technical one the editor doesn't agree with.
The issue tracker is the only way to get a solution that differs with the conclusions that Hixie reaches based on the available evidence

I understand why all this childish splitting of specs is going on (HTML, HTML5, whatever) but this isn't just about the WHATWG and the W3C. It's harmful to authors trying to understand this stuff. Why bother publicly publishing this stuff at all if it's going to be made as confusing as possible to figure out exactly what is published where.
e.g. for people who have different priorities
If one person can use the issue tracker to sabotage a specification, I'd say there's a problem with the process.
adactio: It's not exactly a secret that there's a problem with w3c process
adactio: please let the chairs know
its not super confusibg - if u wanna follow HTML5 - go to http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/spec.html
hsivonen: I feel that might be somewhat like pissing in the wind.
*confusing
adactio: In any case, authors will likely agree with one side. Deletionists will use the W3C drafts, Inclusionists will use WHATWG's :)
adactio, most people here aren't big fans of the W3C.  They're only involved for political reasons: name-brand recognition, patent policies, better chance of MS participation, etc.
By all means, complain to the chairs.
cardona507: I've been pointing interested people to the nice short URL http://whatwg.org/html5 ...which no longer points to a specification called HTML5. It's fucking Orwellian.
And/or the Director.
adactio: I'm sure the redirect could be updated
daedb: I don't have a strong opinion about multiple-vs-single specs, but at least "a prettier [better defined] version of HTML4" is still a worthwhile deliverable.
adactio, most of us probably agree with you, not much point complaining to us.
At least on some aspects.
If it were up to the WHATWG, there'd probably be only one spec, called just "HTML", except maybe you could access it split into several pieces if you preferred.
webben: Sure, but it's just getting more and more watered-down to the point where it's getting less and less interesting to authors.
Or maybe it would still be called HTML5, just it would evolve over time anyway.
That would drive the versioning fans nuts :)
it'd prolly be still called web apps 1.0
adactio: Would you prefer to point people at the spec that is stable and feature-frozen at version 5, or the version that is continually evolving with experiental new features?
daedb, I don't really agree with that at all.  The big stuff is <video>, <audio>, <canvas>, things like that.  <details> and kin are sugar at best.
<video> isn't an unlikely candidate for removal...
isn't sure which authors would want
daedb: Most of the authorship is not interested in specs anyway. <video> being on MDC or in Mark's Dive Into book, for instance, is more important than which of W3C's/WHATWG's docs it sits in.

I think you are missing my point. It is better to move small chunks to a standard that requires implementation.
What if TCP/IP had been one single spec, including ARP, DHCP, BGP, EIGRP, CIDR, etc?
Maybe we could have had less acronyms then…
That would make my students happy!
Analogies are like fraternal twins, they aren't really the same at all
Well, they're half the same, on average.
Each web browser is expected to implement all of CSS3, whereas no software is expected to implement all those IP protocols
You have obviously not heard of an operating system - well perhaps we could say it does not have to implement all routing protocols, but a few hundred others I did not mention instead.
(...as long as you don't consider something like IOS to be a single piece of software)
Which I did, as well as the *nix's and Windoze and the BSD's, etc.
The modularity of an OS seems completely different to the modularity of a web browser implementation
itpastorn: it's at best disingenuous to suggest that people here haven't "heard of an operating system," don't you think?
So, if everything a browser is expected to implement, why not have image formats, SVG, MathML and HTTP, FTP... in the spec as well
Because then no currently-existing browser could handle the entire spec.  There are clear technical limitations to how large the spec can be.  ^_^

Is there a difference between the whatwg and w3c specs for html5?
the "whatwg html" spec is a superset of the w3c html5 spec -- it has features that aren't yet in the w3c copy, like <device>, and it puts everything in one document instead of several
(the whatwg currently also has an "html5" spec that's identical to the w3c "core and vocabulary" one, but i think that's just causing confusion so i might just drop it)
So which is this one? http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/
that's the "whatwg html" spec, which is the "latest version" of html, with more features than html5.
Plural?
<device> and <details>, currently

Okay so http://whatwg.org/html and http://whatwg.org/html5 both point to the same document which is the HTML+HTML5 spec, and then there is also http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/html5/ which is just the HTML5 spec?
yeah
i think i'll drop the latter one though
as it is just causing confusion
